Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis, Reactivity and Mechanisms of Group 4 Metallocene Catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration: The Inorganic, Bioinorganic and Organometallic Chemistry Program supports the research of Professor Richard F. Jordan of the University of Chicago to design general methods for the syntheses of enantiopure group 4 metallocenes and libraries of the new catalysts for applications in asymmetric catalysis. The new chiral metallocenes enable the development of new catalytic, stereoselective C-H functionalization reactions that can be applied in organic syntheses and in the syntheses of novel polymers that contain heterocycles in the main chain. The studies of the d0-metal alkene and alkyne complexes provide new insights to the structures, thermodynamics, kinetics, dynamic properties, and insertion mechanisms of these species. The synthesis of chiral compounds is of critical importance in the pharmaceutical and polymer chemical industries. This project provides valuable research training for undergraduates at the University of Chicago, Lake Forest College, and other Chicago-area undergraduate schools. The project also offers exciting science experiences for high school students from the Chicago Public School system through the University of Chicago Collegiate Scholars Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The development of efficient methods for the synthesis of complex organic molecules and polymers is centrally important in chemistry and related fields where the design and control of materials and phenomena at the molecular level is required to achieve targeted properties and behavior. This project has focused on fundamental aspects of the chemistry of organometallic "catalysts", i.e. metal complexes that function as "molecular machines" that mediate bond-forming and bond-breaking reactions of organic substrates to effect conversion to value-added products. A new strategy for the stereoselective synthesis of chiral zirconium-based catalysts (i.e. those that exist in left-handed and right-handed forms) has been developed that exploits a reversible ligand exchange reaction. These catalysts will be useful for the synthesis of chiral organic molecules that are used in the pharmaceutical and agricultural chemicals industries. Fundamental studies of catalysts that polymerize olefins such as ethylene to polyolefin plastics such as polyethylene have been carried out. Investigations of the structures, dynamics and reactivity of metal alkyl and metal alkyl-olefin species that play central roles in olefin polymerization catalysis have provided insights to polymerization mechanisms, which will be useful in the development of new single-site polymerization catalysts. New classes of organometallic complexes have been investigated, including zirconium and hafnium bis- and tris-pyrazolylborate complexes, cationic palladium halide complexes, and neutral and anionic palladium alkyl complexes that contain electronically unsymmetrical ancillary ligands such as phosphine-sulfonate, phosphine-trifluoroborate and N-heterocyclic-carbene-sulfonate ligands. These systems were used for fundamental mechanistic studies and as platforms for the exploration of new reactivity. The results of this project will inform the development of new generations of olefin polymerization catalysts with the ability to produce new kinds of polyolefins plastics, including functionalized polyethylenes, and the development of new approaches to the conversion of carbon dioxide to useful chemicals. In the long term, these advances will impact the fields of polymer chemistry, materials science, green catalysis and sustainable chemistry.

 

Broader Impact. This project has contributed to the development of human resources in science and technology through the education and mentoring of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, undergraduates and high school students. Students have received rigorous training in organometallic and inorganic chemistry, mechanisms, spectroscopic and analytical methods, synthesis, catalysis, polymer chemistry, computational chemistry and safety, all of which are important in chemistry and related disciplines. This project has also provided opportunities for training in problem-solving strategies, oral and written communication, leadership, ethics and other professional skills. The combination of a broad interdisciplinary knowledge base, cutting-edge research experience, and direct exposure to both target-oriented and fundamental exploratory research gained from participating in this program will enable the students to make significant contributions to the US academic and industrial establishments. Postdoctoral fellows and graduate students who participated in this project have moved on to industrial research and academic positions, and undergraduates who worked on this project are now in top graduate programs in Chemistry.
